title: Approaches to Play and Learning: 3-5 Years
subject: Early Childhood Standards of Quality (2022-)

document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

4E976FBC44A843CB9B685AEC75ED1AEA.description:
Imitate or reiterate things family members have said, such as “My mom
says…”

A920EF66CF054A108FDEF1DD47F3EF7D.description: During mealtime, point out that “Zeinab can only eat halal meat,” and another child answers, “Well, my family doesn’t eat any meat!”

AE2325CD2C974AD385C46E15A0AC8AB6.description:
Notice and discuss differences between families’ beliefs, structures, and
expectations.

B1E2575C50E14E24B1D00D770C5DBF06.description:
Tell about their own family and cultural traditions and notice differences and
similarities when others share their stories. “I have Hanukkah and Devon
has Christmas, but we both get presents!”

784D752D166144BBA8B99B8D7A82CCDC.description:
Notice and ask questions about differences in physical characteristics. For
example: “My skin is dark. Why is Liana’s skin so light?” and “Joy has black
hair but mine is yellow.”

CFE3F6706D254AA2AD8B05E5D27E214C.description: Consider another’s perspective in their learning and interactions.

405EA4CEBEBB4ED1B43D447FE82361A1.description: Try not to tell someone about a surprise gift or event

0E6750B2457744D7AA606873ACD30BBD.description: Wait to eat dessert until the end of their meal.

E546BBFE163249DAB60AB768A3E1FBB8.description:
Use a paintbrush for an art project because they remember not liking the
texture of the paint on their hands.

2E767153BE944AAB94DD206845DD1945.description:
Participate in a group cooking experience, helping to measure the
ingredients and then wait for the food to be ready before getting to taste it.

6D433A27868143F4A352DD6D7E46E6D5.description:
Engage in a new activity for a short time before returning to a favorite toy or
activity..

4C5F9B5A1EB648E6817F522DA9043881.description:
Manage their actions and the ways they communicate, increasingly referring to their previous
experiences.

BABB7F9A3C624C7E832FE4DEB06157E0.description: Use self-talk and breathing techniques to help them manage strong emotions.

2588DA6BD1C94C999F0CC8F618FA7B7F.description: Explain why they are angry, sad, frustrated, etc.

B5714558BE8E44FF9F66C321226108B6.description: With adult reminders, take deep breaths and/or talk through their emotions.

63FFBF6F6DDF4FE7BC2B774A884DFDD9.description: Tell someone they are being “mean” or doing something upsetting.

1AB0433055584C8B8D89A8E42DCEDEA6.description: Express frustration by stomping their feet or making a growling sound.

4B5C9C95B88E462B9DC6E51E4E7019B2.description: Walk away from an upsetting situation.

48A4A618D1A349439CBB02D43A290087.description: With adult guidance, take deep breaths to calm themselves.

945DB22DE9C44DB7BA2B907022F29BCD.description:
Ask a familiar adult for help in handling another child’s actions, such as
asking another child to stop doing something.

FE5743B2312749D2A674EF6E3BF5BF4D.description: Manage the ways they express difficult or strong emotions.

16000F5E0CE2498DB8FD38C55703C5AC.description: Children develop an increasing ability to manage their emotions and behaviors.

F32C6712495345ED8F6EE4BA3C3CD2B7.description: Discuss who will take which role during pretend play.

D9D562E1EE744B25A1A10556A6C2D1CA.description: Negotiate with other children to decide who goes first in a game.

B7FC53917D324E65BFF07F650327BDD5.description: Figure out how many snacks are needed for the whole group.

1D3C8DE696BC4909886A0AC43B4A7309.description:
Begin to use specific strategies to remember and find matches in a memory
card game.

49238FCBFC464E798719B1CEF253765C.description:
Actively participate in a large group discussion to create a list of
expectations for the learning environment.

B06BD09D7CE84E209DC60043CC01AD4A.description: Use a ruler or wand to reach a toy that slid underneath a shelf.

14C35D9204BD411BA07F0DEC759FFEAF.description: Work with other children to complete a floor puzzle.

5CF467E2F2E348199DF3362C3E95205C.description: Demonstrate a growing capacity to make meaning, find a solution, or figure something out.

89B3F89F2906450981E3D9C8E01D35F6.description:
Ask a familiar adult or another child to hold the top of a block structure as
they build the “tallest” tower.

5E824FE14EDB4C3CBE29EF8D7C9AA456.description: Ask a familiar adult to start a new program on the computer.

62ADF50A10C74CFE8AC15F320366081B.description: Ask a familiar adult to write their name on their artwork.

9FDC5C619B1D418B9CFDAAAE7E11213E.description: Identify when to seek support with a challenging task.

4598F07F68A24679BF5ED0614CAE60AB.description: Climb the rock wall on a play structure.

677C18C4DFDA420CA2E4508DAC9116D8.description: Try to zip their coat or tie their shoe.

B80986F6E8C04D9D85E5A1210AFA8A42.description: Try to buckle their own car seat.

AE1987C9760B4F5CB689FD93756490A1.description: Set aside fear of failure when beginning a new or challenging task.

65B0734D4AC34E99A58C7B24C9403ACF.description:
Complete a cycle of activity (select materials, work to their satisfaction,
clean up, return materials), such as choosing a glitter pen and butterfly
paper, writing a brief letter to their grandparents, putting the letter into their
backpack, and returning the pen and extra paper to the shelf.

51BDB2EC996E45968C7C33ABC47185CD.description:
Keep working on an activity even after another child interrupts to show them
something.

65AC4306953C4E15829B188776317E9A.description:
Respond “I’ll come play as soon as I’m done” when another child invites
them to play.

3E25BCC85DA54AEEBC100AAA170D2C26.description: Begin to explore longer books that may be read over a period of several days.

218FD240F25D4632AB3AFCDC307A5A59.description:
Return to a drawing, story, or journal entry over a period of days to add more
content or detail.

CFA7AD223032426A94EE65BCA4B785F4.description:
Continue working on a puzzle until they are finished, while other children
move on to another activity.

3EEA140575F94F33AF6FD6BEF1BADF31.description: Retry or attempt a new strategy to rebuild a fallen block tower.

1BB93B31319B44E9BFA08000EC15D8B0.description:
Ask an adult to save an activity or project so they can continue working on it
later.

01614DEC6946401A9307561CA14929B9.description: Continue working on a painting until they are satisfied with the results.

B7D14DA0220F4EAFACCB485AD77356A9.description: Persist in trying to tie their shoe.

8F25D5E8483B491C9F165FE05A399C51.description: Look for a missing piece in a puzzle and then return to working on the puzzle.

F0C1E25C1F8646639025AF99862FDC1B.description:
With adult support, work on a puzzle for a short time while other children
work on other puzzles.

55ECAF11E9504AFEAD4D6B003F435B1B.description: Persist in trying to zip their coat.

4E2CEC4F7E0D478D839DBBF45B24F51C.description: Show an increasing ability to maintain concentration, persist in, and complete a variety of tasks.

F15D42521914411F855E00EBD68CB909.description: Begin mixing ingredients to make playdough independently.

A9E88C1E559B462C91B017B5EB4C9F89.description: Choose a math activity over an art activity.

C5D1463D019A474A92DB64A6FA0CA923.description: Read a story they wrote aloud to familiar adults and children.

AC99B2F32821484DBC817F108F355F40.description: Show a preference for where to sit during large group time.

FD804E7F07524AF09F63F0633C02C048.description: Save a seat for a friend.

16DE7EECCD7F4A0DA4B7F3D2F80A0B34.description: Bring a favorite book or toy from home to show others.

AAA4C33CEA7D41C88B06C826180E5D72.description: Ask to use alphabet stamps from the writing area so they can finish their painting.

B584859AA71A42608CCDBD84F1A0DDA5.description: Repeatedly ask for the same story to be read.

5881E7E08E2D4BCD8717A49512772F54.description: Share stories about what their family did over the weekend.

0B204F9128FC4981915CA50B5AF1E135.description: Express and share their own interests, ideas, or opinions freely.

D02FF3B918D64D25892F79757F10AC8B.description:
Children engage in explorations and interactions with
confidence.

3D8B0289E0E743669884D9CA85BE16D8.description:
Guess how long it will take for a snowball to melt after they bring it inside,
and then set a timer to test their prediction.

A4AFCC90042B4626B5E5C4B6FB35DD58.description: Use art scraps to build a bridge.

5532C7B03910462FA85E95B6B03F4220.description: Suggest a new ending to a familiar story.

46BB2AD663F8457182614A5F59832AC8.description:
Participate in a discussion about what plants need to grow and draw pictures
of the way the seed they planted is growing.

CA93581C6B7F4A9D80E1425DDB20C869.description: Capture a caterpillar to have as a pet.

31176C037B4C40A2881BD5FC08418203.description: Suggest that two friends arguing over a toy can take turns with it.

A50F711FF34945E3BDEC869D31A2A0CA.description:
With adult support, predict that a car going down a ramp will go faster than
one rolling across a flat floor.

C635DA11BD63479B8C9505601D8D7DA7.description:
Take a connecting-block construction apart and put it back together in a new
way.

F17C26D568D549DEA97CA697A87A01AC.description: Stack blocks to make a tower.

C2F7213F3AA943888D2378A43D86417C.description: Propose and explore possibilities for how things work, what they might do, or what they might be.

6D744575ACE2439099DB8F97631881E3.description:
Set up chairs and other props to represent an experience they’ve had, such
as being on an airplane, and ask other children to pretend to be characters
like the flight attendant, pilot, and passengers.

80CC079BD25B4B95BC13C0EC62EFC146.description: Build a crib out of blocks to use in pretend play.

DFF1DF5153AC47C3A5FBF34BCDA82494.description: Use a stuffed animal as a “baby” in pretend play.

FA2762A3E4DA48D2B4AD1AECE14A303C.description: Make up stories, songs, and dances.

D022713CDA6446ED90C7031B0063907D.description: Sing a song they made up.

7F24F157380D4EABB0BD049659D9B90B.description:
Use yellow and orange paint to paint a picture of how sunny it was
yesterday.

1F7AC3F8741041F68BFD60134A273DD5.description: Demonstrate imagination and creativity in their play.

BD36C3F828E44912B97ED1B6704E6438.description:
Collaborate with other children to develop, share, and follow rules or
expectations in their play together.

40C123B67085465C91F0584616138C26.description: Propose ideas to expand a block city by adding a fire station.

691899AC3DBE4FE39A24ADACCB819F8D.description:
During interactive and shared writing experiences, contribute to the group
story without speaking over other children.

8A2635D5BF7642AF89F7C348CC5B0355.description: Listen to other children share their journal entries.

2042493C97434A67B26C91D03F048AFA.description:
Suggest that a child joining the play can be “the uncle” or “another
superhero.”

104602BBA6624A48BEA2ED2C1993C031.description:
Follow a suggestion that they will pretend to be superheroes rescuing
someone in their outdoor play.

6AB96AACD6664E2B887AFE35EDFEAFB4.description:
Pass dishes during a family-style meal and wait for another child to pour the
juice.

142F1392379F42B7B5BD31D52F9184BC.description: Wait until a timer goes off to signal their turn at the computer.

B39AAB61AE854567B56C74D4890404D6.description: Play a simple board game with other children.

3129D9D18E7D4F94B7A7FC486A544558.description: Accept invitations from other children to join in their games and pretend play.

2566BDDA7A2E400C9A82D9CB902FD144.description: Invite other children to join in pretend play or games.

9CF60E68498B4586BC90000039391B78.description: Begin to show preferences in who they play with.

7A0C5806558C441FA96A3F2EB121BCEF.description: Wait for their turn in a line to go down the slide.

9FC50ABB0E96460783618F86451D7D7E.description:
Play with blocks “with” another child, but without coordinating what they are
each building.

E7A8518B0B75438C9017726CE84F784E.description: Initiate, join, and take turns in play with others.

380A2B394BC041B988FECFBCC6377472.description: Children demonstrate increasingly complex play styles.

C94483AC4ED940D98332B7F3C9F50C15.description:
Recognize that each child has their own likes and dislikes. For example:
“Sierra doesn’t like peas, but I do!”

F96D0CA9575D4466BF7A79565950D01C.description:
Use the correct names of different types of dinosaurs—identifying something
as “a stegosaurus” rather than “a dinosaur.”

B418A63D73A546C18200DED46D5B1AC9.description:
Read and request stories about people going camping after their family
plans a camping trip.

D592D9B2C7CE4A1F9BE0525B636DE218.description:
Adapt their behaviors based on the setting and situation – such as being
quiet in a library or running on the playground.

D8CDBC8D56A34D528B13B0352A9C467D.description:
When looking at pictures of everyone’s families, ask another child, “Is that
your dad in that picture? This is a picture of my mom!”

8F7960FB174E4D61B50C93BB65356F80.description:
Discuss and compare the ways their family is the same as and different from
others. “I have two sisters, but you only have one.”

43697B9997BE473BACC0818BC4307F87.description: Try a new food they’re hesitant about it and discover they like it.

F6D5D33CFBFF40898CD5C55251344C62.description:
Notice that someone has changed their hair cut or color and tell others about
it.

CB9209FB049C479E81A6A1F13A4A5106.description: Repeat or copy friends’ words and actions.

4F8ED6F761EC4FD48803FB6434A3C7D1.description: Reconstruct their ideas about the world around them based on new thoughts and information.

293B69883C404BDE952366155D52B0D9.description: Pull a toy car backward across the floor to find out if it will roll forward on its own.

A438E9FD713644AFA9AAD7F72171085D.description: Use a magnifying glass to look at varying leaf patterns.

2EBB3A6CA8B64FE291A6F50BBC5D315D.description:
Use digital technology and/or books to find information about astronauts and
space.

B4DED2EEA7514F2C98B463DCB7B0A2E1.description:
Ask questions about their observations, and other things that interest
them, such as “Why are the leaves yellow?” and “Why don’t you like to eat
oranges?”

CF59B9048BEE41F6B7C68BB3FC902369.description: Use twigs and rocks to build a small structure.

E28EDC56B69C42289721F2F7D07C5E81.description: Try using blocks of different sizes to balance a scale.

2BBEAFE03B824473831916ADAF4DB491.description: Ask a familiar adult why another child is crying.

A48511B9267C45678C5CE608F7D9F4EC.description: Mix colors together when painting and notice how the colors change.

4B2D1B25E1144A5692C4E247E2A15BC7.description: Throw a ball straight down at the sidewalk to see how high it will bounce.

94440A5B8FE943CEAB4C9624AF6764EE.description: Watch the ants move around in an ant farm.

CFFF0039A6914B928BB525DE729B338C.description: Explore, investigate, and ask questions about the world around them.

C7F830C038114DAAA75C990B87CF825D.description: Assign roles as part of pretend play.

4666688A29E74D1CBB9E016BDF17D6A0.description:
Use interactive technology and/or other materials to create a story with other
children.

19A86D896BA4405B8BF39FE8653E6C1E.description: Use props as part of pretend play.

6CDE4F866F654D669D8F2187C35482D5.description: Ask other children to join them in pretend play.

C7BBF31CE3E846E588B15390DFCBA9F0.description: Pretend to be a firefighter when playing with dramatic play props.

2183BF0A8C614C4592C8609049E7A287.description: Play “house” or other pretend games alongside other children.

20C27BDD005144659DC0E024D90F44CD.description: Use felt pieces to recreate a story told by an adult.

A9A8D764C13C4D33BD07A66CA39CA2FA.description: Use play to interpret and understand the world around them.

4FEDC06F99094AC5AC8633B88D83768F.description:
Children learn about themselves and the world around them through purposeful
play.
